image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: (Son of Compton Ignatius White), a Representative from Idaho; born in Spokane, Wash., December 19, 1920; attended the public schools of Clark Fork, Idaho, and Washington, D.C.; attended George Washington University, Washington, D.C., 1938-1939 and the University of Idaho at Moscow, 1939-1942; engaged as breeder of livestock, and also in mining and logging; during the Second World War was an analysis and experimental flight test engineer for Boeing Aircraft, Co., Seattle, Wash.; member of school board and Clark Fork Board of Trustees, serving as chairman, 1947-1950; candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in 1960; mayor of Clark Fork, 1958-1962; elected as a Democrat to the Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Congresses (January 3, 1963-January 3, 1967); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1966 to the Ninetieth Congress; consultant, Department of the Treasury, 1967; resumed ranching pursuits; member, Clark Fork City Council; died in Sandpoint, Idaho, on October 19, 1998; interment in the White Family Cemetery, east of Clark Fork, Idaho.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Doyle, Randall Jordan. A Political Dynasty In North Idaho, 1933-1967: Compton White, Sr. & Compton White, Jr.: Two Men, Two Visions, Two Fates. Foreword by Howard Zinn. Lanham, MD: University Press of America, 2004.

researchRecord.name: 1966, 16 commercials on 1 film reel.
researchRecord.description: The commercials were used during Compton White's campaign for the 1966 U.S. congressional election in District 1 of Idaho, Democratic Party.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication

researchRecord.name: 1963-1966, 29 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Compton White, Jr., mainly consist of correspondence between White and his constituents, legislation introduced by White and others, and copies of statements presented to congressional committees. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Harold Lough, 1957-1968, 3.1 feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Compton I. White, Jr.
